blurb: Dashcam footage shows Officer Worden punching Maher in the face while other officers had him pinned down. Police claimed to be investigating illegal drug and alcohol use, while Maher claims to have only been smoking a cigarrette.
headline1: Lawsuits: Officer Used Excessive Force In Several Cases
outcome: Worden was fired by Enfield Police Department after an internal affairs investigation. After he filed a grievance against the town, Worden firing was changed to a resignation and he received a $10,000 settlement. At the time, he was named in 6 civil lawsuits.
headline: Lawsuits: Officer Used Excessive Force In Several Cases

outcome: Hartford Police Dept. disciplined 5 officers; Colon received a 90 day suspension and was denied a promotion. The other four officers are getting a 4 day suspension, a 2 day suspension, oral reprimands. Sean Spell (retired) was charged with assault

blurb: Medina was the subject of an arrest warrant from July 9th. He fled on that day. After a violent struggle caught on video by the restaurant, Medina was charged with resisting arrest, sale of a controlled substance, possession of less than four ounces of marijuana and possession of a controlled substance within 1,500 feet of a school. The off duty officer put a gun to both Medina and Mykeel Mitchell. Mitchell, a friend of Medina's, was charged with interfering with an officer after Medina asked him to retrieve the marijuana and money that the cop stripped off him.
headline1: Medina
publication3: Medina was the subject of an arrest warrant from July 9th. He fled on that day. officer: Robert Ranfone, Kershen Bissette, Craig Michalowski and Carlos Roman
blurb: "The lawsuit claimed Cash was stopped after officers crashed their vehicles into a car she was driving, in order to stop her... According to an internal affairs probe, the officers investigating the purse-snatching took Cash out of the car at gunpoint, ticketed her outside of their jurisdiction, illegally seized the vehicle and had it towed where officers wouldn’t release it without their permission. Cash was locked in the back of the police cruiser, interrogated, threatened with arrest and held “hostage” until she provided information about the purse-snatching and led police to the house of someone they believed to be involved, according to the internal affairs report, which deemed it unconstitutional. A purse and license inside Cash’s vehicle also were taken by police, an illegal seizure, according to the investigation. They then dropped the woman, 7½ months pregnant, on the side of a road in “a strange neighborhood” in New Haven without money or a way to get home."
headline1: East Haven settles civil rights suit filed by New Haven woman for $55,000
headline2: New Haven woman sues East Haven police for allegedly violating civil rights
headline: East Haven settles civil rights suit filed by New Haven woman for $55,000;New Haven woman sues East Haven police for allegedly violating civil rights

blurb:
"Schwesinger, a Greenwich resident, claims he was en route to Greenwich Hospital, where his wife had been taken, when he was stopped by Officer Daniel Hendrie because Schwesinger was using a cell phone while behind the wheel of his vehicle.

The traffic stop took an alleged violent turn and Schwesinger claims he suffered eye, shoulder and neck injuries in an altercation with Hendrie, who Schwesinger says unfairly arrested him on a charge of resisting."
headline1: Excessive Force Lawsuit Against Greenwich Police Reportedly Heads To Jury Trial
headline: Excessive Force Lawsuit Against Greenwich Police Reportedly Heads To Jury Trial
